Award.AwardTitle: Probing Film Morphology and Ionic Transport in Organic Semiconductors
Award.AbstractNarration:
Nontechnical description: Polymers that simultaneously conduct both electrons and ions are of technological interest as signal transducers that can interface biological systems with the world of modern digital electronics. The project uses unique microscopy tools to provide a fundamental understanding of how the processing and structure of these polymers affects their ability to conduct ions, and how the transport of ions in turn affects the conduction of electrons through the material. The scientific knowledge from this project impacts technological applications for improving the materials performance of polymers in bioelectronics, and also stands to benefit broader applications such as polymer binders for use in electrochemical energy storage, and potentially also electronic materials for energy harvesting applications. This project additionally builds on the strong track record of the principal investigator in education by developing distinct scalable outreach materials as part of a recently created ambassadors project that trains students to conduct outreach. The project includes direct support for undergraduate research, and addresses pipeline issues facing under-represented groups in the sciences by cementing a successful partnership the principal investigator has undertaken with the Rainier Scholars organization.

Technical description: The scientific goal of this project is to gain a fundamental understanding of the relationship between film processing, local structure, and ion transport in conjugated polymer thin films, with an emphasis on understanding the role of local heterogeneity. Conjugated polymers have recently emerged as promising materials for transducing signals at the interface between the biological and digital environments. This project explores fundamental structure/function properties of these materials as relevant to such applications by applying a unique set of scanning probe microscopy methods. Specifically, the project employs electrochemical strain microscopy to make local measurements of ion motion in conjugated polymer films. In addition, local scanning probe potentiometry of planar device structures doped with ions enables better understanding of structural origins of dispersive ionic transport. Finally, the unique capabilities of time-resolved electrostatic force microscopy are exploited to study electronic, ionic, and structural relaxation dynamics occurring over more than 6 orders of magnitude in time, but with sub-diffraction resolution. Importantly, the project studies the coevolution of structure and function using in situ imaging with environmental (temperature, solvent, dopant, bias) control to understand how structure and function correlate in mixed ionic / electronic transport materials properties in real space.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Materials that can conduct both ions and electrons are increasingly important for a growing number of applications including biosensing, electrochemical charge storage, and neuromorphic computing. In this class of materials, it has historically been difficult to decouple ionic and electronic motion with bulk measurement techniques. In particular, the ability to separate electronic and electronic transport in soft materials, with both high temporal resolution and nanoscale spatial resolution, has been a gap in scientific capability.

To address this gap, this Division of Materials Research grant has enabled the development and application of novel AFM techniques that provide insight into ion transport processes within soft polymeric materials. First, we demonstrated electrochemical strain microscopy (ESM) as a powerful technique for imaging where ions enter polymer films. We used this technique to show that ions preferentially enter polymer films in the amorphous regions. Additionally, we used ESM to show that the identity of the ion had a strong effect on its ability to inject into the film. Next, we developed time-resolved electrostatic force microscopy (trEFM) to measure time dependent processes in ion conducting polymers with nanoscale spatial resolution. We demonstrated trEFM on a block copolymer system that has applications towards solid-state electrolytes for energy storage applications. These imaging techniques yielded new insights into the tradeoff between electronic and ionic transport within this class of materials. With these insights, we were able to develop and study several new mixed ion/electronic conductors, most notably a record performance n-type mixed conductor.

The developed techniques for imaging of nanoscale ion transport within conjugated polymers will prove to be valuable tools for diagnosing and improving future devices that rely on mixed ionic/electronic transport. We envision these techniques being applied to improve solid-state electrolytes for batteries, develop improved polymer electrodes, improve materials design for biosensing applications, and creation more stable devices for neuromorphic computing.


Last Modified: 10/28/2019
Modified by: David S Ginger

Images (1 of )
  • The top row illustrates the swelling of annealed P3MEEMT. In this sample the swelling disrupts the electronic conduction pathways. The bottom row illustrates swelling in unannealed P3MEEMT. Despite greater overall swelling, the electronic pathways are maintained in this sample.
    Connor Bischak
    David S Ginger
    Swelling of a Mixed Ionic/Electronic Conductor
  • Schematic illustrating the instrumentation for collecting ESM data. Briefly, an AC bias is applied to the tip, inducing ion uptake in the polymer. This ion ingress causes a swelling of the polymer which can be detected with picometer sensitivity by the AFM tip.
    Rajiv Giridharagopal
    Public Domain
    David S Ginger
    Electrochemical Strain Microscopy
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Materials that can conduct both ions and electrons are increasingly important for a growing number of applications including biosensing, electrochemical charge storage, and neuromorphic computing. In this class of materials, it has historically been difficult to decouple ionic and electronic motion with bulk measurement techniques. In particular, the ability to separate electronic and electronic transport in soft materials, with both high temporal resolution and nanoscale spatial resolution, has been a gap in scientific capability. To address this gap, this Division of Materials Research grant has enabled the development and application of novel AFM techniques that provide insight into ion transport processes within soft polymeric materials. First, we demonstrated electrochemical strain microscopy (ESM) as a powerful technique for imaging where ions enter polymer films. We used this technique to show that ions preferentially enter polymer films in the amorphous regions. Additionally, we used ESM to show that the identity of the ion had a strong effect on its ability to inject into the film. Next, we developed time-resolved electrostatic force microscopy (trEFM) to measure time dependent processes in ion conducting polymers with nanoscale spatial resolution. We demonstrated trEFM on a block copolymer system that has applications towards solid-state electrolytes for energy storage applications. These imaging techniques yielded new insights into the tradeoff between electronic and ionic transport within this class of materials. With these insights, we were able to develop and study several new mixed ion/electronic conductors, most notably a record performance n-type mixed conductor. The developed techniques for imaging of nanoscale ion transport within conjugated polymers will prove to be valuable tools for diagnosing and improving future devices that rely on mixed ionic/electronic transport.
